description: Shui – fluid, location of the nose Gui – swamp egg Located in the philtrum, which looks like a canal Located between the nose which receives the 5 types of CHI from heaven and the mouth which receives the 5 tastes from the earth, GV26 is like man who stands between heaven and earth
location: In the philtrum, 1/3rd of the distance from the base of the nose to the tip of the upper lip
functions:
Meeting with ST, receives a branch from ST
Meeting with CO, receives a branch from CO
Resuscitation point
Purifies the SHEN
secondary_functions:
1. Expels wind
2. Returns consciousness
3. Treats acute pain of the lower spinal vertebra
4. Used to revive after fainting
chinese_pinyin_hebrew: REN ZHONG / SHUI GUO - 人中/水溝
english_name_hebrew: Human Center / Water Passage - מרכז האדם / מעבר המים
etymology_hebrew:
Shui (水) – נוזל, מיקום האף
Gui (溝) – תעלת ביצה
ממוקם במרזב האפי (פילטרום), שנראה כמו תעלה.
ממוקם בין האף, שמקבל את 5 סוגי ה-CHI מהשמיים, לבין הפה, שמקבל את 5 הטעמים מהאדמה. GV26 הוא כמו האדם העומד בין שמים וארץ.
description_hebrew: Shui – נוזל, מיקום האף Gui – תעלת ביצה ממוקם במרזב האפי (פילטרום), שנראה כמו תעלה. ממוקם בין האף, שמקבל את 5 סוגי ה-CHI מהשמיים, לבין הפה, שמקבל את 5 הטעמים מהאדמה. GV26 הוא כמו האדם העומד בין שמים וארץ.
location_hebrew: במרזב האפי (פילטרום), בשליש המרחק מבסיס האף לקצה השפה העליונה.
functions_hebrew:
נקודת מפגש עם ST (קיבה), מקבלת ענף מ-ST.
נקודת מפגש עם CO (מעי גס), מקבלת ענף מ-CO.
נקודת החייאה.
מטהרת את ה-SHEN (נפש).
secondary_functions_hebrew:
1. מסלקת רוח.
2. מחזירה הכרה.
3. מטפלת בכאב חד של חוליות הגב התחתון.
4. משמשת להחייאה לאחר התעלפות.

description: Dui– sharp, hole Dan – end, tip Referring to the point’s location. The I Ching explains that “Dui” is the mouth
location: At the lower tip of the philtrum, where it meets the upper part of the lip
functions: 1. Purifies heat, nourishes fluids, benefits the mouth, calms the soul
etymology_hebrew: Dui – חד, חור; Dan – סוף, קצה. מתייחס למיקום הנקודה. האי צ'ינג מסביר ש"Dui" הוא הפה.
description_hebrew: Dui – חד, חור; Dan – סוף, קצה. מתייחס למיקום הנקודה. האי צ'ינג מסביר ש"Dui" הוא הפה.
location_hebrew: בקצה התחתון של הפילטרום, במקום בו הוא פוגש את החלק העליון של השפה.
functions_hebrew: 1. מטהר חום, מזין נוזלים, מועיל לפה, מרגיע את הנפש.

description: Yin – gums Jiao – crossing
location: In the mouth, where the inner lip meets the front gums
functions: Meeting with ST and CV
cautions: Attachments The attachments are a vital part of the book. it contain a lot of information for the clarity and the success of the treatments Basic rules and contraindications for acupuncture In the following instances one should exercise caution before deciding to use acupuncture and be meticulous in choosing acupuncture points. In cases of exhaustion and fatigue it is preferable to support the patient with moxa on St36 and/or Cv6 If the patient has been fasting there is risk of fainting. It is preferable to eat 30 minutes before receiving acupuncture after a prolonged fast. Do not needle after a heavy meal or if the patient feels stuffed. Exercise caution in needling when the patient is experiencing an extreme emotional state, e.g. joy or sadness. Needling in these circumstances may result in reverse flow of CHI. Immediately after conception, acupuncture should only be done by a doctor who understands the process of pregnancy from conception through birth and the unique changes in the patterns of CHI flow which take place during this process. 6. Do not needle in instances where there is dissonance between the complexion and the pulse in terms of pattern diagnostics. This shows an energetic imbalance. Breathing techniques should be used to regain balance before using acupuncture. When the weather does not support the treatment, e.g. in extremely stormy weather avoid strong needle stimulation especially when treating acute pathologies. In extreme heat, do not use moxa. When the time of the treatment does not support the treatment, e.g. during the evening and night time avoid strong needle stimulation unless the pathology is strong and acute. PREGNANCY The process of pregnancy is one of upmost importance. The physician must fully understand and support this physiologic process in a very precise manner. The body of a pregnant woman is constantly working to nourish the fetus and sustain the pregnancy. We must have these objectives in mind when treating a pregnant woman. One of the most important things to remember is the energetic balance in her body is markedly different from a state of non-pregnancy. Consequently, there are acupuncture points which would be dangerous to manipulate or cause to return to their prior state of function (as they were before pregnancy).  The reasons for this include the points’ function, the direction in which they send energy, their meeting/influence on other points and the points’ location on the body. Examples CO4 is contraindicated throughout pregnancy. This is due to its strong yang quality which can cause contractions. For this same reason, it is also a very effective point during labor. SP6 is contraindicated for the entire pregnancy because it is responsible for balancing the subtle environmental changes in the womb e.g. dampness and heat. Needling may disrupt this delicate balance. Ren6 is contraindicated because of its location BL23 and DU4 are both contraindicated because of their locations. Also, DU4 has a strong energetic effect on the kidneys and BL23 has a strong connection with the DAI MAI, both systems should be used cautiously during pregnancy. Additional Cautions A pregnant woman who is very weak should not be needled. Exercise extreme caution in treatment if the patient has a history of miscarriages Do not needle a pregnant woman experiencing extreme emotional tension resulting in extreme anger, sadness or anxiety. Do not needle a pregnant woman suffering extreme acute pain in the upper or lower abdomen. Points Forbidden During Pregnancy The beginning of pregnancy is determined according to the time of ovulation and not according to the time of the last menses Points Forbidden with Moxa There are a couple of acupuncture points that per the classics, are contraindicated with moxa. The main reason for this is their proximity to vital blood vessels. The heat from moxa on these points can cause changes to the bodies of these vessels as well as to the flow of blood inside of them. REN-15, SP-9, ST-38, GB-1, ST-9, LU-8 DU-15, DU-16, BL-10, GB-15, TH-23, BL-1, CO-20, Per the Nan Jing the use of the following points is forbidden with moxa. LU- 1,2,3,4,5,8 CO- 4,5,13 ST- 5,7,9,30,42 SP- 11, 12 HT- 1,3 SI- 16 BL- 40 KID- 3,10 PC-8 TH- 22 GB- 2,3 LIV- 2,3,10,11 Body Cun measurements 15 cun medial malleolus – knee joint 16 cun lateral malleolus – knee joint 14 cun posterior knee – gluteal crease 20 cun patella– superior border of symphysis pubis 19 cun knee joint – tuberosity of greater trochanter 2 cun superior border of patella – inferior border of patella 12 cun wrist joint – elbow joint 9 cun elbow joint – superior border of axilla 5 cun superior border of symphysis pubis – umbilicus 8 cun umbilicus – CV16 4 cun CV – line of ASIS 8 cun CV – mid axillary line 8 cun CV – acromion 3 cun GV – medial scapula 4.5 cun mid line – ST8 1.5 cun mid line – BL4 (half way between the inner cantus of the eye and the pupil) 3 cun midline – GB13 14 cun glabella – GV16 15 cun glabella – posterior hairline 3 cun glabella – anterior hairline 8 cun glabella – GV20 6 cun GV20 – GV16 5 Elements Chinese medicine divides the world of phenomenon into 5 elements, or per some translations “5 phases”. Each element has its own unique characteristics be they physical or metaphysical. The elements have a flow and rhythm unique to each one through which they are manifested in the world. Nonphysical associations of the organs include; direction and climate which are ideas associated with heaven.  When speaking of the elements, physical concepts include; taste, the organs themselves, tissue and bodily functions. The elements do not exist as individual entities. They are mutually involved in a closed-circuit relationship where one’s activity influences and is influenced by the activity (or lack thereof) of another. One of the most crucial relationships to be aware of amongst the elements is that of generating and controlling. Understand how the elements interact with each other, gives us a more complete understanding of the person in our care, the signs with which he is presenting and what elements are out of balance. While we consider all the elements when making a diagnosis, it is important to focus on the ones that are dominant and perhaps overcontrolling others. Over control can happen when an element is in a state of excess. Thus, it will seek to control an element that is weak. This will lead to further weakening of the controlled element. The same system of control and generating that exists on the micro level (in living organisms), exists on the macro level (in the universe at large). Their relationship’s and resulting effects can be observed in the climate, seasons, hourly etc. This perspective lays the groundwork for diagnosis and treatment in Chinese Medicine. Also, the food, sounds and emotions that are related to each element give us a deeper understanding of pathology as well as tools for treatment. Transport/Antique points There are 60 acupuncture points that are considered crucial energetic points on the body. These points allow us to balance the meridians in a unique manner per the energy that is needed. On the arm meridians, these points are located between the elbows and fingers. On the leg meridians, they are between the knees and toes. Each of the 12 primary meridians has points labeled; Jing-well, Ying-spring, Shu-stream, Jig-river and He-sea. These points have a direct connection to the 5 phases and the nourishing (sheng) cycle that is constantly at play. On the yin meridians, the first of these points is always associated with the wood element. On the yang meridians, the first will always be a metal point. With an understanding of 5 element theory, one can use these points in a variety of ways to balance and influence the 5 elements in the body. Mother point – This is the point associated with the element that nourishes/births the element of the relevant meridian i.e. LU9 & CO11 are both earth points on metal meridians. These will influence the process of earth nourishing metal. Child point – This is the point associated with the element that is nourished by the relevant meridian. They are also called “dispersal” points because their energetic flow is in the opposite direction of the nourishing cycle i.e. LU5 & CO2 are both water points on metal meridians and thus nourish the metal element with water energy. One should exercise caution when using these points as they cause energy to flow in the opposite direction than its normal coursing. Horary points – Theses are points associated with the element that the relevant meridian belongs to. LU8 and CO1 are metal points on metal meridians. These are generally used for two purposes; to strengthen the characteristic of an element and its influence on the body. Or, during treatments done at the time that the organ/meridian is dominant to increase that systems functionality even more. An example being using LU8 between 3-5 AM to increase the lungs’ metal energy. 5 ELEMENT POINTS 8 EXTRAORDINARY MERIDIANS The 8 extraordinary meridians are opened by using both a “master” and “couple” point. To allow for a good treatment one must follow a few basic rules Needle the master point first and the couple point second. Master points are needled on the left side on men and on the right for women. Couple points are needled on the right side for men and the left for women. When taking needles out, the couple point is removed first and the master point second. During a treatment where and extraordinary meridian is opened, the use of other points on that meridian is contraindicated (see intro to extraordinary points). The duration of needle retention is calculated per the time of day and what organ is dominant at the time of treatment. The practitioner should wait to feel 3 peaks in the pulse of the dominant organ, upon feeling the 3rd, needles are removed e.g. at noon one should wait to feel 3 peaks in the heart pulse. After the 3rd peak is felt, remove the needles in the correct order. Xi – cleft points There is a total of 16 Xi-cleft points on the body. 12 of them belong to the primary meridians and 4 to the 8 extraordinary meridians. “Xi” is used to describe a pool where energy from the meridian accumulates. These points can be used in the following situations. When we want to immediately increase and intensify the flow of energy in a meridian by tapping into the meridians internal reserves and not a deeper place of storage. Acute instances requiring immediate change in energy. Adjusting the direction of flow in the meridian. Xi – cleft points can also be used as reflex points. Palpation of these points can provide us with information regarding the meridians state of excess or deficiency. In deficiency, the point will feel sunken, soft, cold and lacking tension. In a state of excess, they will feel hard, protruding, hot, painful, tense and give exaggerated resistance. Mu Points There are 12 Mu points found on the body, one for each organ. These points have a yin nature and therefore influence the physical aspect of their associated organs. Another sign of these being yin in nature is their location. All of them are found on the anterior aspect of the body (chest, upper and lower abdomen). They are crucial points to influence the body’s function. The Mu points are used to influence the building of yin material of their associated organ. They are not used to influence the energetic aspect of organs. Doing so, is a task reserved for the Shu points. Additionally, Mu points are reflex points of their organs. Mu points Shu Points of the Bladder Meridian BL11 – HUI meeting of the bones. Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower border of spinous process T1 BL13 – SHU meeting point of the lungs Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T3 BL14 – SHU point of the pericardium Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T4 BL15 – SHU point of the heart Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T5 BL16 – SHU point of the DU Mai Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T6 BL17 – HUI meeting point of the blood and SHU point of the diaphragm Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T7 BL18 – SHU point of the liver Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T9 BL19 – SHU point of the gall bladder Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T10 BL20 – SHU point of the spleen Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T11 BL21 – Shu point of the stomach Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T12 BL22 – Shu point of the triple burner Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process L1 BL23 – SHU point of the kidneys Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process L2 BL24 – SHU point of the sea of CHI Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process L3 BL25 – SHU point of the large intestine Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process L4 BL26 – SHU point of the gate of vitality Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process L5 BL27 – SHU point of the small intestine Located 1.5 cun lateral to the first sacral foramen BL28 – SHU point of the urinary bladder Located 1.5 cun lateral to the second sacral foramen BL29 – SHU point of the sacrum Located 1.5 cun lateral to the third sacral foramen BL30 – SHU point of the anus Located 1.5 cun lateral to the fourth sacral foramen Ba Hui Meeting Points There are 8 meeting points on the body. Per the Ling Shu and Nei Ching, these points are used to treat warm disease. Additionally, they can be used to treat the system which they represent. Influential/8 meeting points (BA HUI) TMM Meeting points These points are important in understanding the physiology of the Tendo Muscular Meridians. The TMM, via these points, can stop a pathogen which has made its way into the body from further penetrating. We can tonify the defensive CHI at these areas using the TMM meeting points. DIVERGENT MEETING and EXIT POINTS The divergent meridians serve as a highway taking CHI from the yin meridians to the head. Since the yin meridians do not reach the head and brain, they divert from their main pathways and meet divergent pathways of the yang meridians. It is through these passages that yin CHI arrives at the head and brain. It is important to remember the pathways of the divergents so that we can follow the progression of CHI flow between the left and right side of the body. Shokanten Points Shokanten points are meeting points of the 6 warps. The above chart shows the 6 warps and their Shokanten points. These points are used when the practitioner wishes to do the following: Supporting one of the 6 warps Influencing the expression of an internal climate associated with one of the 6 warps e.g. cold water is influenced by Kid12. It will support the Tai Yang which expresses a climate of cold. Balancing the 9 continents When using Shokanten points one should consider all the above principals particularly the first 2. GROUP LUO POINTS These points can be used to draw upon the CHI of the meridians meeting there, for local or broader systemic energetic influences. Important Reminder: TH8 is a forbidden point in acupuncture. It can be manipulated by way of massage or moxa. The Clock The use of opposites on the Chinese clock is known as “mid-day -mid night”. This is a fundamental law giving us insight to the energetic changes which occur throughout the day.  This principle is rooted in seeing the dynamic balance in cycles of energy. The 24-hour day is divided in to 12 hours of yang dominance (12:00-00:00) and 12 hours of yin dominance (00:00-12:00). Bearing in mind the principle of polarity of yin and yang, the Chinese clock shows us that when an organ is at its energetic peak, another organ (its clock opposite) is experiencing an energetic ebb e.g. at 12:00 pm the heart is at its peak. At the same time gall bladder is experiencing its ebb. This reciprocal waxing and waning of yin and yang is constantly taking place. Clinically this is a very important principle to consider, in that if we tonify an organ we also suppress its clock opposite. During a treatment, one must consider the system being needled and the system that is dominant at the time of the treatment as well as the opposites of each. The reason for this is that if we support an organ in treatment, we can potentially weaken (by suppressing) its clock opposite. THE CHINESE CLOCK MIDDAY MIDNIGHT LAW PULSE In Chinese Medicine the skill of pulse diagnosis is one that the practitioner will hone for the rest of his life. It is the most trustworthy diagnostic tool for the experienced practitioner. At the most basic level of pulse diagnoses, one can differentiate and understand the states of the 3 Jiao and the Zang and Fu organs. As one acquires more skill, the pulses of the 8 extraordinary meridians will begin to be felt more clearly. When the 8 extraordinary are more clear, the practitioner will be able to diagnose disruption in the function of each organ in the body per the 3 all-encompassing aspects of life:  spirit, physical function of each organ and the amount and potential of prenatal Jing available. The pulses introduced here lay the groundwork for the basic initial pulse diagnoses used by practitioners of Classical Chinese Medicine. Classical Pulses Pulses of the 8 Extradoridanry Meridians Nei Ching Pulses Ba Gua The Ba Gua form the underlying philosophy of the book of changes (the I Ching). The central concept of the Ba Gua express’s the interactions   between the energies of heaven and earth and all that exists between them. Every interaction of the Ba Gua results in the actualization of a new phenomenon. This new phenomenon is a direct result of the specific qualities and dynamic relationship of the Ba Gua that brought it into being. The Ba Gua are geometric structures made up of 8 trigrams. Each trigram describes an interaction between yang (represented by a full line) and yin (represented by a broken line). The relationships between the trigrams listed below help us gain perspective on process of creation and the dynamic balancing that is constantly occurring in the universe. The use of what I call I-Ching acupuncture, requires impeccable skill which is acquired through understanding the trigrams, 5 elements, 5 phases, the 4 seasons, the dynamic relationships between organs and meridians, understanding what is felt in the pulse, and the ability to synchronize these things. There is no doubt that without the I – Ching, Chinese Medicine would not have developed to the state that it is in today. I firmly believe that without the understanding of the trigrams, ones understanding of Chinese Medicine will be incomplete. Deep Energy Each organ in the body has a deep energy which activates and preserves the dynamic balance of that organ and thus does so for the entire body. For example, the expanding and contracting of the lungs and large intestine require the motion of the wood element. Without this wood energy, the physiological process of breathing and peristalsis would not be possible. Therefore, when using a meridian one must consider it’s deep energy which influences the body as a unit. If a person is experiencing mental and energetic stagnation, we would not use points on the stomach meridian. Doing so may intensify the innate heaviness of the earth element. On the other hand, using the spleen meridian, may intensify the fire elements energy which can be beneficial in this instance. Meridian                               deep energy                      Point of Influence
etymology_hebrew: Yin - חֲנִיכַיִם, Jiao - צְלִיחָה - יִין - חֲנִיכַיִם, גְ'יַאוֹ - צְלִיחָה
description_hebrew: Yin – חֲנִיכַיִם Jiao – צְלִיחָה - יִין - חֲנִיכַיִם, גְ'יַאוֹ - צְלִיחָה
location_hebrew: In the mouth, where the inner lip meets the front gums - בַּפֶּה, בַּמָּקוֹם בּוֹ הַשָּׂפָה הַפְּנִימִית פּוֹגֶשֶׁת אֶת הַחֲנִיכַיִם הַקִּדְמִיִּים
needling_hebrew: Diagonally upwards, 0.1 – 0.3 cun - בְּאֲלַכְסוֹן כְּלַפֵּי מַעְלָה, 0.1 – 0.3 צוּן
functions_hebrew: Meeting with ST and CV - פְּגִישָׁה עִם מֵרִידְיַאן הַקֵּיבָה (ST) וּמֵרִידְיַאן הַהַתְעָבָּרָה (CV)

These will influence the process of earth nourishing metal. Child point – This is the point associated with the element that is nourished by the relevant meridian. They are also called “dispersal” points because their energetic flow is in the opposite direction of the nourishing cycle i.e. LU5 & CO2 are both water points on metal meridians and thus nourish the metal element with water energy. One should exercise caution when using these points as they cause energy to flow in the opposite direction than its normal coursing. Horary points – Theses are points associated with the element that the relevant meridian belongs to. LU8 and CO1 are metal points on metal meridians. These are generally used for two purposes; to strengthen the characteristic of an element and its influence on the body. Or, during treatments done at the time that the organ/meridian is dominant to increase that systems functionality even more. An example being using LU8 between 3-5 AM to increase the lungs’ metal energy. 5 ELEMENT POINTS 8 EXTRAORDINARY MERIDIANS The 8 extraordinary meridians are opened by using both a “master” and “couple” point. To allow for a good treatment one must follow a few basic rules Needle the master point first and the couple point second. Master points are needled on the left side on men and on the right for women. Couple points are needled on the right side for men and the left for women. When taking needles out, the couple point is removed first and the master point second. During a treatment where and extraordinary meridian is opened, the use of other points on that meridian is contraindicated (see intro to extraordinary points). The duration of needle retention is calculated per the time of day and what organ is dominant at the time of treatment. The practitioner should wait to feel 3 peaks in the pulse of the dominant organ, upon feeling the 3rd, needles are removed e.g. at noon one should wait to feel 3 peaks in the heart pulse. After the 3rd peak is felt, remove the needles in the correct order. Xi – cleft points There is a total of 16 Xi-cleft points on the body. 12 of them belong to the primary meridians and 4 to the 8 extraordinary meridians. “Xi” is used to describe a pool where energy from the meridian accumulates. These points can be used in the following situations. When we want to immediately increase and intensify the flow of energy in a meridian by tapping into the meridians internal reserves and not a deeper place of storage. Acute instances requiring immediate change in energy. Adjusting the direction of flow in the meridian. Xi – cleft points can also be used as reflex points. Palpation of these points can provide us with information regarding the meridians state of excess or deficiency. In deficiency, the point will feel sunken, soft, cold and lacking tension. In a state of excess, they will feel hard, protruding, hot, painful, tense and give exaggerated resistance. Mu Points There are 12 Mu points found on the body, one for each organ. These points have a yin nature and therefore influence the physical aspect of their associated organs. Another sign of these being yin in nature is their location. All of them are found on the anterior aspect of the body (chest, upper and lower abdomen). They are crucial points to influence the body’s function. The Mu points are used to influence the building of yin material of their associated organ. They are not used to influence the energetic aspect of organs. Doing so, is a task reserved for the Shu points. Additionally, Mu points are reflex points of their organs. Mu points Shu Points of the Bladder Meridian BL11 – HUI meeting of the bones. Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower border of spinous process T1 BL13 – SHU meeting point of the lungs Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T3 BL14 – SHU point of the pericardium Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T4 BL15 – SHU point of the heart Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T5 BL16 – SHU point of the DU Mai Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T6 BL17 – HUI meeting point of the blood and SHU point of the diaphragm Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T7 BL18 – SHU point of the liver Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T9 BL19 – SHU point of the gall bladder Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T10 BL20 – SHU point of the spleen Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T11 BL21 – Shu point of the stomach Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T12 BL22 – Shu point of the triple burner Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process L1 BL23 – SHU point of the kidneys Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process L2 BL24 – SHU point of the sea of CHI Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process L3 BL25 – SHU point of the large intestine Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process L4 BL26 – SHU point of the gate of vitality Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process L5 BL27 – SHU point of the small intestine Located 1.5 cun lateral to the first sacral foramen BL28 – SHU point of the urinary bladder Located 1.5 cun lateral to the second sacral foramen BL29 – SHU point of the sacrum Located 1.5 cun lateral to the third sacral foramen BL30 – SHU point of the anus Located 1.5 cun lateral to the fourth sacral foramen Ba Hui Meeting Points There are 8 meeting points on the body. Per the Ling Shu and Nei Ching, these points are used to treat warm disease. Additionally, they can be used to treat the system which they represent. Influential/8 meeting points (BA HUI) TMM Meeting points These points are important in understanding the physiology of the Tendo Muscular Meridians. The TMM, via these points, can stop a pathogen which has made its way into the body from further penetrating. We can tonify the defensive CHI at these areas using the TMM meeting points. DIVERGENT MEETING and EXIT POINTS The divergent meridians serve as a highway taking CHI from the yin meridians to the head. Since the yin meridians do not reach the head and brain, they divert from their main pathways and meet divergent pathways of the yang meridians. It is through these passages that yin CHI arrives at the head and brain. It is important to remember the pathways of the divergents so that we can follow the progression of CHI flow between the left and right side of the body. Shokanten Points Shokanten points are meeting points of the 6 warps. The above chart shows the 6 warps and their Shokanten points. These points are used when the practitioner wishes to do the following: Supporting one of the 6 warps Influencing the expression of an internal climate associated with one of the 6 warps e.g. cold water is influenced by Kid12. It will support the Tai Yang which expresses a climate of cold. Balancing the 9 continents When using Shokanten points one should consider all the above principals particularly the first 2. GROUP LUO POINTS These points can be used to draw upon the CHI of the meridians meeting there, for local or broader systemic energetic influences. Important Reminder: TH8 is a forbidden point in acupuncture. It can be manipulated by way of massage or moxa. The Clock The use of opposites on the Chinese clock is known as “mid-day -mid night”. This is a fundamental law giving us insight to the energetic changes which occur throughout the day.  This principle is rooted in seeing the dynamic balance in cycles of energy. The 24-hour day is divided in to 12 hours of yang dominance (12:00-00:00) and 12 hours of yin dominance (00:00-12:00). Bearing in mind the principle of polarity of yin and yang, the Chinese clock shows us that when an organ is at its energetic peak, another organ (its clock opposite) is experiencing an energetic ebb e.g. at 12:00 pm the heart is at its peak. At the same time gall bladder is experiencing its ebb. This reciprocal waxing and waning of yin and yang is constantly taking place. Clinically this is a very important principle to consider, in that if we tonify an organ we also suppress its clock opposite. During a treatment, one must consider the system being needled and the system that is dominant at the time of the treatment as well as the opposites of each. The reason for this is that if we support an organ in treatment, we can potentially weaken (by suppressing) its clock opposite. THE CHINESE CLOCK MIDDAY MIDNIGHT LAW PULSE In Chinese Medicine the skill of pulse diagnosis is one that the practitioner will hone for the rest of his life. It is the most trustworthy diagnostic tool for the experienced practitioner. At the most basic level of pulse diagnoses, one can differentiate and understand the states of the 3 Jiao and the Zang and Fu organs. As one acquires more skill, the pulses of the 8 extraordinary meridians will begin to be felt more clearly. When the 8 extraordinary are more clear, the practitioner will be able to diagnose disruption in the function of each organ in the body per the 3 all-encompassing aspects of life:  spirit, physical function of each organ and the amount and potential of prenatal Jing available. The pulses introduced here lay the groundwork for the basic initial pulse diagnoses used by practitioners of Classical Chinese Medicine. Classical Pulses Pulses of the 8 Extradoridanry Meridians Nei Ching Pulses Ba Gua The Ba Gua form the underlying philosophy of the book of changes (the I Ching). The central concept of the Ba Gua express’s the interactions   between the energies of heaven and earth and all that exists between them. Every interaction of the Ba Gua results in the actualization of a new phenomenon. This new phenomenon is a direct result of the specific qualities and dynamic relationship of the Ba Gua that brought it into being. The Ba Gua are geometric structures made up of 8 trigrams. Each trigram describes an interaction between yang (represented by a full line) and yin (represented by a broken line). The relationships between the trigrams listed below help us gain perspective on process of creation and the dynamic balancing that is constantly occurring in the universe. The use of what I call I-Ching acupuncture, requires impeccable skill which is acquired through understanding the trigrams, 5 elements, 5 phases, the 4 seasons, the dynamic relationships between organs and meridians, understanding what is felt in the pulse, and the ability to synchronize these things. There is no doubt that without the I – Ching, Chinese Medicine would not have developed to the state that it is in today. I firmly believe that without the understanding of the trigrams, ones understanding of Chinese Medicine will be incomplete. Deep Energy Each organ in the body has a deep energy which activates and preserves the dynamic balance of that organ and thus does so for the entire body. For example, the expanding and contracting of the lungs and large intestine require the motion of the wood element. Without this wood energy, the physiological process of breathing and peristalsis would not be possible. Therefore, when using a meridian one must consider it’s deep energy which influences the body as a unit. If a person is experiencing mental and energetic stagnation, we would not use points on the stomach meridian. Doing so may intensify the innate heaviness of the earth element. On the other hand, using the spleen meridian, may intensify the fire elements energy which can be beneficial in this instance.
